longdesc: Winner of the 2019 Alternate Realities Commission, Spectre is an interactive installation that reveals the secrets of the Digital Influence Industry as you pray to Dataism and the Gods of Silicon Valley. With the help of 'deep-fake' celebrities including Mark Zuckerberg, Marcel Duchamp, Marina Abramović, and Freddie Mercury, Spectre tells a cautionary tale of technology, democracy and society, curated by algorithms and powered by visitors’ data.

shortdesc: Participants in the Advertising Positions project were 3d-scanned and given custom software that collected the online ads they were served over several months. These ads were then applied, one-by-one, to the skin of the user's body and animated in virtual space...
longdesc: This series began with software agents trained to search the web, according to specific user profiles they have been assigned (age, gender, ethnicity, orientation, location, etc.) Driving a modified version of the Chrome browser, these agents periodically visited sites that they 'liked', and clicked links they selected, bringing them to new pages. This process continued over several months, during which all they collected all of the advertisements they were served, based on their profile. In more recent iterations, human volunteers are 3d-scanned and given custom software to collect the ads they receiveserved over several months  (generally several thousands of them). Each ad is then applied to a single polygon on the mesh skin of an avatar that we create and release into virtual space.

shortdesc: A scripting language and toolkit for interactive generative dialog in games and conversational interfaces. Dialogic organically integrates generative and scripted content, allowing characters to respond naturally to game events and arbitrary inputs from users.

An aesthetically-oriented system of software agents that explore human reading and writing behaviors in the face of ubiquitous algorithmic and networked services. Each reader is uniquely coded to embody a specific strategy for consuming language…
longdesc:
The Readers Project is an aesthetically-oriented system of software entities that explores the culture of human reading and writing in the face of ubiquitous networked services. The ‘readers’ we create navigate texts according to strategies they derive from linguistic feature analysis and real-time probability data they harvest from search engines. Installations from the project have been featured and commissioned at a number of international venues, and papers have been published in peer-reviewed journals including Leonardo, Siggraph and ISEA.

A conceptual novel derived from the project, entitled How It Is in Common Tongues, presents a computational critique of copyright and the shrinking of the linguistic commons. The most recent installation of The Readers Project, The Real Story of Ah-Q, premiered in October at ‘Connecting Spaces HK-Zurich’ and critically examined the role of language, narrative, and censorship in the context of contemporary China.

shortdesc: Designed to support the creation of novel works of computational literature, RiTa is a free and open-source, natural language toolkit (for Java, JavaScript, Android and Node) that provides a unique set of tools for artists, writers and digital humanists interested in working with programmable media.
longdesc: Designed to support the creation of novel works of generative literature, the RiTa library (for Java, JavaScript, Android and Node) provides a unique set of tools for artists and writers working in programmable media. RiTa is designed to be easy-to-use while still enabling a range of tasks, from grammar and Markov-based generation to stemming, splitting, conjugation, pos-tagging, rhyming, metrics, and feature analysis (stresses, phonemes, syllables, etc). RiTa, implemented in both Java and JavaScript, is free/libre and open-source, and optionally runs in the popular Processing and p5.js environments for arts programming.

shortdesc: AdNauseam is the open-source browser extension (banned by Google and recommended by Mozilla) that hides users' interests from advertising networks and attempts, by clicking every ad that it finds, to subvert the very economic system that drives online surveillance and datafication.
longdesc:
AdNauseam is one of several recent projects focusing on the browser as a site for artistic intervention. Like an ad-blocker, AdNauseam hides ads on visited pages, but then clicks each ad in the background, polluting user profiles and creating mistrust between advertisers and the networks they pay for clicks.

Further, by allowing users to explore visualizations of the ads they are served, AdNauseam creates a space for 'sousveillance', providing an algorithmic glimpse into the profiles taken and stored without our consent. The project was recently presented at Eyebeam, MIT, and the New School, covered by Wired magazine, and featured at Transmediale in Berlin.

AdNauseam developed from an earlier project entitled TrackMeNot, which similarly protected users from data profiling by issuing generated decoy queries to search engines. Users' real searches are hidden in a cloud of false data (see links below).

shortdesc: A conceptual novel and algorithmic provocation against the ongoing theft of the cultural commons by entities like Google. The novel, quite closely resembling Samuel Beckett's 'How It Is', is composed solely of fragments of text written by other authors as found in Google Books…
longtitle: How It Is in Common Tongues
longdesc:
How It Is in Common Tongues is a conceptual novel and provocation against copyright composed by searching for the text of Samuel Beckett's How It Is in Google Books, attempting to find, in sequence, the longest common phrases from the work composed by writers other than Beckett. Each phrase is then cited with a footnote providing the shortest URL found for the phrase (in addition to the date and the total number of occurrences found). The result is a word-for-word remake of the original Beckett text, with every single phrase cited with its location in the largest linguistic commons in human history, as written by someone else.

How It Is in Common Tongues is one output of the Readers Project (see link below), an aesthetically-oriented system of software entities that autonomously explore the culture of human reading in the face of ubiquitous networked services.

shortdesc: In 2005, we posted a binding Terms of Service agreement with a unique clause stating that if any entity were to use automated means to crawl the site (as Google has done consistently since), then the databases in which this data was stored would become the property of the rednoise collective
longtitle: All your Google are Belong to Us

shortdesc: An algorithmic process reads through Adam Smith’s Wealth of Nations, highlighting the longest phrases written by others, unconnected with Smith or his book. Each phrase is then re-read via a live Google search, showing how they would be found now, complete with images and targeted advertising.
longdesc: An algorithmic process reads through Adam Smith’s An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations (1776), highlighting phrases, up to six words in length, that might have been written by any of us. We know that we might have composed these successive short sequences of words because a search engine has found them on web pages unconnected with Smith and his book. The software reader then sends our phrases to another process which re-searches and re-reads these phrases on Google and other portals, seeking to discover other causes for the wealth of nations now.

shortdesc: Automatype is a networked installation (composed of analog TV monitors and RaspberryPIs running custom software) that uses algorithms to find the bridges between English words, six-degrees-of-Kevin-Bacon-style; not bridges of garbled nonsense, but English words that are often strangely resonant…
longdesc: Automatype is a networked installation (composed of analog TV monitors and RaspberryPIs running custom software) that explores the creation of aesthetic, linguistic meaning via anticipation, juxtaposition, and association. The algorithm at the heart of the work continually computes the minimum number of substitutions required to transform each valid English word into the next, deriving a near infinite number of combinations of words and phrases, letter-by-letter, substitution-by-substitution.

shortdesc: Minor Distance is an album of generative music, distributed by Cotton Goods Records, which begins with Howe's improvised guitar, played through his Pataclysm software (a real-time probabilistic sampler) and Seaman's delicate piano figures…

videos.title: Theoretical Architectures, directed by Josh Gibson, is one of several videos created for the album, Minor Distance

longdesc: Minor Distance (Cotton Goods Records) is a collaboration between Howe and Bill Seaman realized after the two exchanged ideas while both travelling separately—in effect making for an album recorded between Seoul, Bremen, Frankfurt, Berlin, Thailand, China and New York—covering more than the "Minor Distance" referred to in the title. The recordings began with Howe's improvised guitar recordings, played live-to-tape through his bespoke probablistic sampler software (Pataclysm), and Seaman's simple piano loops…

quotes.text: The uncanny ability of this recording to evoke snatches of work well removed from the genre: Miles floating a single trumpet note toward the ceiling of that deconsecrated Armenium church in "So What". The way that the piano appears out of the rain on those divine Blue Nile recordings. The grave and resolute brass in Johan Johanssen's "Miner's Hymns". Moments of beauty that leap the gap like a spark across the air… I will keep these recordings near to hand.
Howe's noise-meets-Ry-Cooder electric guitar fills gravitate like a swarm of metallic dragon flies…
